elements.content: Hexacyanidochromate­(III) anion is here explored as the building block for the construction of bimetallic 3d-4f coordination polymers that combine spin ordering and luminescence. We report the two-dimensional cyanido-bridged {[NdIII(pmmo)2­(H2O)3]­[CrIII(CN)6]} (1) layered framework obtained by the spontaneous crystallization from the aqueous solution of Nd3+, pyrimidine N-oxide (pmmo), and [CrIII(CN)6]3–. 1 crystallizes as light green plates in the orthorhombic Pbca space group and reveals a topology of a square grid built of nine-coordinated [NdIII(μ-NC)4­(H2O)3­(pmmo)2]− complexes of a nearly capped square antiprism geometry, and six-coordinated octahedral [CrIII(CN)6]3– moieties. Because of the presence of cyanide-mediated ferromagnetic coupling between paramagnetic NdIII (J = 9/2) and CrIII (S = 3/2) centers, 1 exhibits a long-range ferromagnetic ordering below Curie temperature of 2.8 K, with a tiny magnetization-field hysteresis loop detected at 1.8 K. Under the UV light irradiation, 1 shows the near-infrared fluorescence originated from the 4F3/2 → 4I9/2 (λmax = 895 nm) and 4F3/2 → 4I11/2 (λmax = 1060 nm) electronic transitions of NdIII. The near-infrared emission is realized through the energy transfer from [CrIII(CN)6]3– anions and pmmo ligands to NdIII centers which was possible due to the spectral overlap between the visible-light and near-infrared emission bands of CrIII and pmmo, and the absorption bands of NdIII. Thus, 1 can be considered as a novel type of bifunctional magneto-luminescent layered material taking advantage of the fruitful electronic and magnetic interplay between NdIII(pmmo) and [CrIII(CN)6]3– complexes.

elements.content: Hexacyanidochromate­(III) anion was presented to be the useful molecular building block in the construction of near-infrared emitting ferromagnetic materials. This cyanide complex was combined with Nd3+ and pyrimidine N-oxide (pmmo) in the aqueous solution which resulted in the layered {[NdIII(pmmo)2­(H2O)3]­[CrIII(CN)6]} (1) framework that combines a long-range ferromagnetic ordering and a Nd3+-centered near-infrared emission sensitized both by Cr3+ and organic ligand.
elements.clean_text: Hexacyanidochromate(III) anion was presented to be the useful molecular building block in the construction of near-infrared emitting ferromagnetic materials. This cyanide complex was combined with Nd3+ and pyrimidine N-oxide (pmmo) in the aqueous solution which resulted in the layered {[NdIII(pmmo)2(H2O)3][CrIII(CN)6]} (1) framework that combines a long-range ferromagnetic ordering and a Nd3+-centered near-infrared emission sensitized both by Cr3+ and organic ligand.

elements.content: Since the late 1990s, we have witnessed the increasing scientific interest in the investigation of heterobimetallic cyanido-bridged coordination polymers revealing a diversity of structural topologies, including clusters, chains, layers, and three-dimensional networks. These coordination assemblies arouse a great attention due to their magnetic properties, that are magnetic ordering, slow relaxation of magnetization, and charge transfer or spin transitions. They are also explored as the versatile molecular platforms for the implementation of multifunctionality. Polycyanidometallates were employed in the preparation of microporous magnets, magnetic sponges, photomagnets, molecular multiferroics, and chiral magnets. It was shown that the interaction between the additional property and the intrinsic magnetic nature results in the unique cooperative effects, such as magnetization induced second harmonic generation (MSHG), or a 90-degree photoswitching of SHG polarization plane, found for the coupling between chirality, photoinduced phase transition, and magnetic ordering.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since the late 1990s, we have witnessed the increasing scientific interest in the investigation of heterobimetallic cyanido-bridged coordination polymers revealing a diversity of structural topologies, including clusters, chains, layers, and three-dimensional networks. These coordination assemblies arouse a great attention due to their magnetic properties, that are magnetic ordering, slow relaxation of magnetization, and charge transfer or spin transitions. They are also explored as the versatile molecular platforms for the implementation of multifunctionality. Polycyanidometallates were employed in the preparation of microporous magnets, magnetic sponges, photomagnets, molecular multiferroics, and chiral magnets. It was shown that the interaction between the additional property and the intrinsic magnetic nature results in the unique cooperative effects, such as magnetization induced second harmonic generation (MSHG), or a 90-degree photoswitching of SHG polarization plane, found for the coupling between chirality, photoinduced phase transition, and magnetic ordering.

elements.content: Multifunctionality of cyanido-bridged coordination polymers is also realized through the combination of luminescence with long-range magnetic ordering. Such emissive molecule-based magnet has to be constructed of building blocks that can ensure both magnetic coupling and a distinct luminescent signal. This is, however, difficult to achieve as most of the cyanide complexes of transition metal ions are not emissive due to the preferred nonradiative relaxation through a number of low lying excited states. This could be partially overcome by the application of octacyanidometallates of Mo­(V) and W­(V) which are not emissive, but they are transparent in the visible (above ca. 400–450 nm) and the near-infrared range. Thus, they allow the detection of lanthanide- or ligand-based luminescence. Following this idea, our group and others reported a series of unique luminescent cyanide-based magnets built of the [MoV(CN)8]3– or [WV(CN)8]3– ions bonded to the complexes of 4f metal ions. Among them, the important optical effects, such as green to red luminescence switchable by excitation light, or visible emission realized by ligand to metal energy transfer, were shown to coexist with the ferromagnetic ordering. A few emissive molecule-based magnets built of very different, oxamato-, and carboxylato-bridged assemblies were also reported, and their potential in multimodal sensing was investigated.
elements.clean_text: Multifunctionality of cyanido-bridged coordination polymers is also realized through the combination of luminescence with long-range magnetic ordering. Such emissive molecule-based magnet has to be constructed of building blocks that can ensure both magnetic coupling and a distinct luminescent signal. This is, however, difficult to achieve as most of the cyanide complexes of transition metal ions are not emissive due to the preferred nonradiative relaxation through a number of low lying excited states. This could be partially overcome by the application of octacyanidometallates of Mo(V) and W(V) which are not emissive, but they are transparent in the visible (above ca. 400-450 nm) and the near-infrared range. Thus, they allow the detection of lanthanide- or ligand-based luminescence. Following this idea, our group and others reported a series of unique luminescent cyanide-based magnets built of the [MoV(CN)8]3- or [WV(CN)8]3- ions bonded to the complexes of 4f metal ions. Among them, the important optical effects, such as green to red luminescence switchable by excitation light, or visible emission realized by ligand to metal energy transfer, were shown to coexist with the ferromagnetic ordering. elements.content: In this context, there is a great challenge to employ the polycyanidometallates that can be both paramagnetic and emissive giving significant contribution not only to the magnetic but also to the overall optical properties of bimetallic coordination polymer. The hexacyanidochromate­(III) complex seems to be a good candidate for such magneto-luminescent materials due to its paramagnetism (3d3 valence configuration giving S = 3/2), and phosphorescence in the near-infrared range around 820 nm of the 2Eg → 4A2g transition, reported at low temperatures in the K3[CrIII(CN)6] salt. Hexacyanidochromate­(III)-based coordination assemblies were broadly investigated due to their relatively high critical temperatures of magnetic ordering, including the highest T c of ca. 100 °C among cyanido-bridged molecule-based magnets, but they were not explored as the source of novel magneto-luminescent materials. In the single report, [CrIII(CN)6]3– was presented to be phosphorescent in the classical three-dimensional {[GdIII(H2O)2]­[CrIII(CN)6]}­·2H2O network, whose crystal structure and magnetism were reported 40 years ago. Therefore, we focused our effort on the preparation of [CrIII(CN)6]-based magnets that can reveal emission properties. To form the bimetallic assembly, we decided to explore the complexes of lanthanide­(3+) cations which exhibit a diversity of luminescent effects. In particular, NdIII is well-known for its near-infrared (NIR) emission which can be widely applied in bioimaging, night vision, optical communications, and computing. The interaction between NdIII and [CrIII(CN)6]3– is expected to be fruitful, and it should include the efficient sensitization of NIR lanthanide emission by CrIII, as was proven in various bimetallic Nd–Cr complexes, and the cyanido-bridged {[NdIII(H2O)2­(dmf)4]­[CrIII(CN)6]}­·nH2O chains. Except for the canonical {[NdIII(H2O)2]­[CrIII(CN)6]}­·2H2O network showing magnetic ordering below 6 K, the other reported Nd–Cr hexacyanido-bridged assemblies are very rare and include only binuclear dimers and coordination chains, not revealing the magnetic ordering. To control the topology of the coordination polymer, and to add the additional possible source of emission, we examined pyridine- and pyrimidine-based derivatives, which are known to play an essential role in the multifunctionality of bimetallic cyanido-bridged coordination frameworks. We thus report the synthesis, crystal structure, and magnetic and optical properties of {[NdIII(pmmo)2­(H2O)3]­[CrIII(CN)6]} (1) (pmmo = pyrimidine N-oxide) layered material that reveal the long-range ferromagnetic ordering coexisting with the near-infrared NdIII-centered fluorescence realized by the energy transfer from both the organic ligand and hexacyanidochromate­(III) anions to 4f metal ion.

elements.content:
All reagents, NdIIICl3·6H2O, K3[CrIII(CN)6], and pyrimidine N-oxide (pmmo, CAS: 17043-94-6) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification.

Synthesis of <bold>1</bold>

The 23.3 mg (0.065 mmol) portion of NdIIICl3·6H2O and the 12.5 mg (0.13 mmol) portion of pmmo were dissolved together in a minimal amount of water (0.3 mL) and heated to reach the boiling point. The resulting hot solution was quickly added to the freshly prepared solution of K3[CrIII(CN)6] (21.2 mg, 0.065 mmol), also dissolved in a small amount of water (0.3 mL). The mixture was stirred for several seconds, filtrated, and left in the dark for crystallization. The greenish platelet crystals of 1 started to appear after a few minutes. They were collected by the suction filtration, washed with water and ethanol, and dried in the air. The resulting monocrystalline material was stable during exposition on the air, and it was identified by the composition of {[NdIII(pmmo)2­(H2O)3]­[CrIII(CN)6]} (1) as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, and the CHN elemental analysis, supported by the thermogravimetric analysis (Figure S1). Yield: 13.0 mg, 33.4%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2156m, 2148m, 2136s, 2129m indicate that cyanides of [CrIII(CN)6]3– ions in 1 are both terminal and bridging. Others: 3590m, 3180s,br, O–H hydrogen bonding; 3110s, 3095s, stretching C–H; 1660m, δ­(H2O); 1595w, 1561m, 1556m, 1483m, 1475m, 1427vs, 1335w, 1253vs, 1230s, 1169w, 1124m, 1066w, 1059w, 1048w, 959vw, 929vw, 909vw, 860m, 853w, 831w, 819w, 688m, 680w, 652w, 588m, 576w, 519w, vibrational transitions of pmmo, including ν­(N–O) of 1253vs and various ν­(CC), ν­(CN), C–H and ring deformation. CHN elemental analysis. Anal. Calcd for Nd1Cr1C14H14N10O5 (1, M W = 598.56 g·mol–1): C, 28.1%; H, 2.4%; N, 23.4%. Found: C, 27.7%; H, 2.5%; N, 23.1%.

Experimental Section

Materials

All reagents, NdIIICl3⋅6H2O, K3[CrIII(CN)6], and pyrimidine N-oxide (pmmo, CAS: 17043-94-6) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification.

Synthesis of 1 

The 23.3 mg (0.065 mmol) portion of NdIIICl3⋅6H2O and the 12.5 mg (0.13 mmol) portion of pmmo were dissolved together in a minimal amount of water (0.3 mL) and heated to reach the boiling point. The resulting hot solution was quickly added to the freshly prepared solution of K3[CrIII(CN)6] (21.2 mg, 0.065 mmol), also dissolved in a small amount of water (0.3 mL). The mixture was stirred for several seconds, filtrated, and left in the dark for crystallization. The greenish platelet crystals of 1 started to appear after a few minutes. They were collected by the suction filtration, washed with water and ethanol, and dried in the air. The resulting monocrystalline material was stable during exposition on the air, and it was identified by the composition of {[NdIII(pmmo)2(H2O)3][CrIII(CN)6]} (1) as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, and the CHN elemental analysis, supported by the thermogravimetric analysis (Figure S1). Yield: 13.0 mg, 33.4%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm-1). CN- stretching vibrations: 2156m, 2148m, 2136s, 2129m indicate that cyanides of [CrIII(CN)6]3- ions in 1 are both terminal and bridging. Others: 3590m, 3180s,br, O-H hydrogen bonding; 3110s, 3095s, stretching C-H; 1660m, δ(H2O); 1595w, 1561m, 1556m, 1483m, 1475m, 1427vs, 1335w, 1253vs, 1230s, 1169w, 1124m, 1066w, 1059w, 1048w, 959vw, 929vw, 909vw, 860m, 853w, 831w, 819w, 688m, 680w, 652w, 588m, 576w, 519w, vibrational transitions of pmmo, including ν(N-O) of 1253vs and various ν(CC), ν(CN), C-H and ring deformation. CHN elemental analysis. Anal. Calcd for Nd1Cr1C14H14N10O5 (1, M W = 598.56 g⋅mol-1): C, 28.1%; H, 2.4%; N, 23.4%. Found: C, 27.7%; H, 2.5%; N, 23.1%.

elements.content: Single crystal diffraction analysis of 1 was performed using a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The single crystal was dispersed in a paratone-N oil, mounted on Micro Mounts holder, and measured at the low temperature of 80(2) K. The crystal structure was solved by a direct method using SHELXS-97 and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique using SHELXL-2014/7. Calculations were executed using partially Crystal Structure crystallographic software package and partially WinGX (ver. 1.80.05) integrated system. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of coordinated water molecules were found independently from the electron density map, but their thermal ellipsoids were refined using a riding model. The selected carbon atoms of cyanides and pmmo ligands reveal some degree of structural disorder, which affects the refinement process. Thus, the restraints on their thermal ellipsoids (DELU, ISOR) were applied. Structural diagrams were prepared using Mercury 3.5.1 software. The CCDC reference number for the crystal structure of 1 is 1457095. The details of the crystal data and structure refinement of 1 are presented in .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystal diffraction analysis of 1 was performed using a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The single crystal was dispersed in a paratone-N oil, mounted on Micro Mounts holder, and measured at the low temperature of 80(2) K. The crystal structure was solved by a direct method using SHELXS-97 and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique using SHELXL-2014/7. Calculations were executed using partially Crystal Structure crystallographic software package and partially WinGX (ver. 1.80.05) integrated system. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of coordinated water molecules were found independently from the electron density map, but their thermal ellipsoids were refined using a riding model. The selected carbon atoms of cyanides and pmmo ligands reveal some degree of structural disorder, which affects the refinement process. Thus, the restraints on their thermal ellipsoids (DELU, ISOR) were applied. Structural diagrams were prepared using Mercury 3.5.1 software. The CCDC reference number for the crystal structure of 1 is 1457095. The details of the crystal data and structure refinement of 1 are presented in .

Infrared spectrum of 1 was measured using a Jasco FTIR-4100 spectrometer on the pellet made of the polycrystalline sample mixed with KBr. Thermogravimetric curve was collected on a Rigaku Thermo Plus TG8120 in the 20–400 °C range under an air atmosphere with a heating rate of 1 °C·min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the polycrystalline sample of 1 was collected on a Rigaku Ultima-IV with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The UV–vis-NIR diffuse reflectance spectrum was measured using a Jasco V-670 spectrophotometer on the polycrystalline sample grinded with BaSO4. The UV–vis-NIR emission and excitation spectra were collected on a Horiba Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog-3 (FL3-211) spectrofluorimeter (model TKN-7) with an Xe (450 W) lamp as an excitation source. For the UV–vis range (250–850 nm), the room temperature R928P emission detector in a photon-counting mode was applied. For measurements in the near-infrared region (800–1550 nm), a liquid nitrogen cooled version of InGaAs photodiode detector DSS-IGA020L was used. The collection and analysis of the emission and excitation data were conducted using Fluoressence software. The spectra were corrected for the background signal of the holder and the lamp intensity. The measurements were executed at room temperature in the standard solid state holder, or at low temperature of 77 K in the optical cryostat cooled by liquid N2. Magnetic measurements were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS XL magnetometer on the polycrystalline sample submerged in paraffin oil to avoid the rotation of crystallites under the applied magnetic field.

elements.content:
Continuous shape measure analysis for the determination of the geometry of nine-coordinated NdIII complexes of 1 was performed using SHAPE software ver. 2.1.

Results and DiscussionSynthesis and Crystal Structure

Light green platelet crystals of 1 were prepared by mixing a hot aqueous solution of NdIIICl3·6H2O and pmmo with a cold aqueous solution of K3[CrIII(CN)6]. The synthetic conditions were adjusted to accelerate the crystallization to the period of a few minutes in order to avoid the partial hydrolysis of [CrIII(CN)6]3–. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicated that 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pbca space group as bimetallic cyanido-bridged layers of a square grid topology (, ; also see Tables S1–S2 and Figures S2–S3 in the Supporting Information). The layered coordination skeleton is built of {Nd2Cr2(CN)4} units involving two [CrIII(CN)6]3– ions alternately arranged with two [NdIII(H2O)3­(pmmo)2]3+ complexes (a). The asymmetric unit contains one [CrIII(CN)6]3– and one NdIII complex (b). The [CrIII(CN)6]3– ion forms four cyanide bridges and exhibits the geometry of a nearly ideal octahedron (Table S1). NdIII coordinates four nitrogen atoms of cyanides in the closely square planar arrangement, two oxygen atoms of two pmmo ligands with 70.5(2)° between them, and three oxygen atoms of water molecules. This results in the coordination number of nine and the geometry of a distorted capped square antiprism (CSAPR-9, C 4v symmetry) as proven by the continuous shape measure analysis (Table S2). The layers of 1 are situated within the bc crystallographic plane, and their separation is controlled by the terminal cyanides and pmmo ligands which are aligned almost perpendicular to the layers (c and S2). The interlayer interactions consist of the hydrogen bonds bonding terminal cyanides with water molecules (N5–O4, N6–O5), nitrogen atoms of pmmo with water molecules (N8–O5, N10–O4), and oxygen atoms of pmmo with water molecules (O1–O3, Figure S3 and Table S1). Noteworthy, 1 does not contain any crystallization solvent molecules in the interlayer space. The closest Nd–Cr distance between neighboring layers is ca. 8.1 Å, while the respective distances within the layers are in the range of 5.69–5.79 Å.

elements.content: In addition to the single crystal analysis, the powder X-ray diffraction pattern was performed on the polycrystalline sample of 1. The experimental diffractogram corresponds well to the pattern calculated from the respective structural model determined in the single-crystal studies (Figure S4). This indicates a good purity of the obtained solid phase, and the validity of the structural model for the bulk sample used in the magnetic and optical measurements.

elements.content: The direct-current (dc) magnetic properties of 1 are presented in . The molar magnetic susceptibility–temperature product (χM T) reaches at room temperature 3.3 cm3 mol–1 K for {NdIII–CrIII} unit which is slightly lower than the value of 3.5 cm3 mol–1 K expected for the uncoupled NdIII (J = 9/2, g J = 8/11) – CrIII (S = 3/2, g = 2) pair. On cooling, χM T very slowly decreases to the shallow minimum of 3.0 cm3 mol–1 K around 40 K (a). These features are related to the thermal depopulation of the mJ levels arising from the splitting of the 4I9/2 ground multiplet of NdIII rather than to the possible antiferromagnetic correlation. At the lower temperatures, the χM T product increases strongly to the impressive maximum of 26.1 cm3 mol–1 K detected at 2.5 K (a, the inset). This obviously has to be ascribed to the cyanide-mediated magnetic coupling within the Nd–NC–Cr linkages. The type of magnetic interactions is indicated by the field dependence of the molar magnetization measured at 1.8 K (c, the inset). The magnetization reveals the fast increase with the increasing field, being almost saturated at 50 kOe. The related value at the highest available field is 4.35 μB, which is very close to the value 4.25 μB calculated for the parallel arrangement of NdIII (S eff = 1/2, g eff = 2.5) and CrIII (S = 3/2, g = 2) magnetic moments. At the same time, the experimental magnetization at 50 kOe is much higher than 1.75 μB expected for the antiferromagnetically coupled NdIII–CrIII units, proving the presence of the ferromagnetic coupling in 1.

elements.content: The χM T versus T plot revealed the maximum at 2.5 K which can be assigned to the saturation of magnetization, indicating the onset of long-range magnetic ordering in 1. This phenomenon is nicely visible in the field-cooled magnetization (FCM) plots gathered in the 1.8–10 K range at various small magnetic fields of 10, 20, 30, and 50 Oe (b). FCM curves exhibit the abrupt increase of the signal below 3 K with a further saturation at the lowest temperatures, which is a very characteristic feature of the transition to the ferromagnetic state. The determination of the Curie temperature (T C) was performed by the analysis of the first derivative of FCM plots in the function of temperature (b, the inset). Thus, 1 was found to become a ferromagnet below the T C of 2.8 K. As expected for a ferromagnet, 1 shows the magnetic hysteresis loop in the M–H plot at 1.8 K, with a very small coercive field of ca. 10 Oe (c), which indicates the soft character of this ferromagnet, expected due to the very weak magnetic anisotropy of both NdIII and CrIII magnetic centers. The magnetic phase transition in 1 was also confirmed by the alternate-current (ac) magnetic properties investigated by means of the temperature dependences of in-plane (χM′) and out-of-plane (χM″) components of the complex molar magnetic susceptibility (Figure S5). Both the χM′–T and χM″–T plots exhibit the frequency independent maxima, which supports the presence of paramagnetic–ferromagnetic phase transition occurring in 1. The T C of 2.6 K estimated from the positions of these maxima is close to that found in the analysis of FCM characteristics.

elements.content: The crystals of 1 reveal light greenish color which corresponds to the weak absorption in the visible region of 390–700 nm dominated by the broad component ranging from the UV part to around 450 nm, and relatively strong sharp band at 580 nm (). The solid state absorption spectrum of 1 was precisely investigated in the broad UV–vis-NIR range from 200 to 1000 nm. In contrast to the visible part of the spectrum, 1 exhibits very strong absorption of the UV light with the three maxima at 260, 290, and 380 nm. The broad and complex UV band with a significant visible tail to around 450 nm was deconvoluted into five components ascribed to the electronic transitions of [CrIII(CN)6]3–, and pmmo, as NdIII should reveal in this range rather sharp and much weaker f–f transitions. As presented in , four bands (1–4) are situated exclusively in the UV range below 350 K, and their maxima were found at 210, 234, 266, and 303 nm, respectively. Bands 1–3 are ascribed to the combined contributions from charge transfer transitions of [CrIII(CN)6]3– and singlet to singlet (π → π*) transitions of pmmo, as detected also in the precursors K3[Cr­(CN)6] and pure pmmo, and in the separately prepared reference sample of the lanthanum-containing analogue with the formula of {[LaIII(pmmo)2­(H2O)3]­[CrIII(CN)6]} (1 La ) (Figures S6–S7, Table S3, and details of the reference samples in Supporting Information). Bands 4 and 5 represent also both the hexacyanidometallate complex and pmmo, as the related transitions of CrIII (4A2g → 4T1g, band 4; 4A2g → 4T2g, band 5) and pmmo (n → π*) can be detected in this range. In addition, one more broad and weak component ranging from the UV to the visible range, and centered at 483 nm, was also found, and it can be assigned mainly to the spin-forbidden transitions of pmmo (triplet → singlet: n → π*), while the additional contribution from the 4A2g → 2T2g transition of CrIII, positioned in this range, should much smaller. The Vis-NIR part of the spectrum between 465 and 870 nm is dominated by a series of sharp bands ascribed to the f–f electronic transitions of NdIII (bands 7–14) as those bands are not observed in the lanthanum-containing 1 La reference (Figure S7). The respective maxima are situated at 465, 516, 579, 626, 681, 744, 798, and 870 nm, respectively, and they can be interpreted in terms of the transitions from 4I9/2 ground multiplet to the 2G9/2, 4G11/2, 2K15/2 (band 7), 4G7/2, 4G9/2, 2K13/2 (band 8), 2G7/2, 4G5/2 (band 9), 2H11/2 (band 10), 4F9/2 (band 11), 4S3/2, 4F7/2 (band 12), 2H9/2, 4F5/2 (band 13), and 4F3/2 (band 14) excited states of NdIII.

elements.content: The luminescence properties of 1 were investigated by solid state emission and excitation spectra at room temperature (). Exploring the strong absorption of the UV light, 1 was excited by the light of 375 nm, and the luminescence in the near-infrared range was detected. This emission consists of two rather sharp bands with the maxima at 895 and 1060 nm. They can be assigned to the NdIII-centered f–f transitions from the emissive 4F3/2 multiplet to the 4I9/2 and 4I11/2 states, respectively (a and S8–S9). 1 does not reveal any other emission bands in the Vis-NIR range, even though the green phosphorescence of pure pmmo around 545 nm and the NIR phosphorescence of free [CrIII(CN)6]3– around 820 nm could have been observed (Figure S8). In addition, the photoluminescence of the 1 La reference sample, containing the optically silent LaIII centers instead of NdIII, was also investigated, and both the green phosphorescence of pmmo with a small shift toward higher energy to the maximum at 510 nm together with the much smaller and also slightly shifted CrIII-based emission centered at 810 nm were detected (Figure S9). This indicates the efficient energy transfer from both the organic ligand and hexacyanidochromate to the NdIII center in the investigated compound, 1. In fact, the excitation spectrum of 1 is dominated by the broad UV band with the maximum at 380 nm and a shoulder at 320 nm, which can ascribed to [CrIII(CN)6]3– and pmmo, revealing characteristic absorption in this range (b). The direct excitation of NdIII is also possible as a series of sharp excitation f-centered bands were found in the Vis-NIR range. However, the strongest NdIII-based band at 577 nm, interpreted in terms of 4I9/2 → 2G7/2, 4G5/2 transitions, is four times weaker than the UV-centered maximum at 380 nm, indicating that the energy transfer process is far more efficient than the direct f-centered excitation.

elements.content: The efficient ligand-to-metal and metal-to-metal energy transfer processes in 1 can be attributed to the good spectroscopic overlap between the emission bands of [CrIII(CN)6]3– and pmmo energy donors and the absorption f–f bands of the energy accepting NdIII centers (Figure S10). The broad emission band of pmmo, observed both in the free ligand and in the lanthanum-based reference, 1 La , related to the 3T1 → 1S0 (n → π*) phosphorescent transition, overlaps well with a few absorption bands of NdIII, especially relatively stronger bands at 516 and 579 nm, interpreted in terms of 4I9/2 → 4G7/2, 4G9/2, 2K13/2, and 4I9/2 → 2G7/2, 4G5/2 multiple transitions, respectively. Similarly, the phosphorescent 2Eg → 4A2g band of CrIII with the maximum at 824 or 810 nm for K3[Cr­(CN)6] and 1 La , respectively, overlaps nicely with NdIII-based absorption band at 798 nm, which is related to 4I9/2 → 2H9/2, 4F5/2 transitions (Figure S10). In addition, the energy transfer (ET) is also facilitated by the short Nd–Cr distances and the intermetallic cyanide bridges in the case of CrIII → NdIII ET, and a direct coordination of pmmo through oxygen atoms to NdIII centers.

elements.content: From the above considerations, we were able to draw the scheme of the possible processes occurring after the UV light excitation in 1 (c). The excitation UV light of the selected 375 nm wavelength is absorbed efficiently both by pmmo and [CrIII(CN)6]3– moieties due to the presence of suitable excited states, and the related spin allowed absorption transitions. This is followed by the nonradiative relaxation (intersystem crossing) to the long-lived emissive states: triplet state of pmmo, and 2Eg state of CrIII. Later, instead of the d-centered or ligand-based emission, the energy is transferred to NdIII which is possible due to the closely lying excited multiplets of 4f metal ion. After that, the energy is quickly relaxed to the emissive 4I9/2 state of NdIII, and the near-infrared fluorescence to the 4I11/2 and 4I9/2 multiplets is detected. This behavior is observed at room temperature, but it is also maintained at a low temperature of 77 K (Figure S11), suggesting that the thermally activated energy back transfer from NdIII to ligand or CrIII is not observed.

After that, the energy is quickly relaxed to the emissive 4I9/2 state of NdIII, and the near-infrared fluorescence to the 4I11/2 and 4I9/2 multiplets is detected. This behavior is observed at room temperature, but it is also maintained at a low temperature of 77 K (Figure S11), suggesting that the thermally activated energy back transfer from NdIII to ligand or CrIII is not observed.

elements.content: We report the two-dimensional cyanido-bridged {[NdIII(pmmo)2­(H2O)3]­[CrIII(CN)6]} bifunctional magneto-luminescent coordination polymer that combines ferromagnetism with NdIII-centered near-infrared luminescence sensitized by the excited states of both pyrimidine N-oxide ligand and hexacyanidochromate­(III) anions. Our work proves that the [CrIII(CN)6]3– metalloligand is an attractive molecular building block for the construction of emissive molecule-based magnets realized by various bimetallic coordination topologies. Hexacyanidochromate­(III) anion contributes significantly not only to the magnetic properties, offering the paramagnetic S = 3/2 ground state and six cyanide bridged mediating in the magnetic coupling, but also to the optical properties, as it can serve as an efficient sensitizer for the near-infrared luminescence of trivalent lanthanide ions. The presented material shows the coexistence of two different functionalities, which are magnetic ordering and luminescence. The expected interactions between these two properties could not be, however, observed due to low Curie temperature of 2.8 K. This can be overcome by the preparation of emissive [Cr­(CN)6]-based magnets with the higher T C by the increase of coordination connectivity through cyanide bridges and the partial replacement of NdIII by GdIII revealing higher ground state spin of S = 7/2, or by the strongly anisotropic TbIII with the 7F6 ground multiplet. Alternatively, the Nd3+ admixtures can be implemented into three-dimensional Prussian Blue analogues frameworks based on 3d metal ions and [Cr­(CN)6]3–, which are well-known for their high critical temperatures of magnetic ordering. Such implementation of strongly interacting near-infrared luminescent {NdIIICrIII} pairs into molecule-based magnets of high T C should result in the extraordinary magnetic control over the emission properties. This promising pathway is now intensively being investigated in our laboratories.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We report the two-dimensional cyanido-bridged {[NdIII(pmmo)2(H2O)3][CrIII(CN)6]} bifunctional magneto-luminescent coordination polymer that combines ferromagnetism with NdIII-centered near-infrared luminescence sensitized by the excited states of both pyrimidine N-oxide ligand and hexacyanidochromate(III) anions. Our work proves that the [CrIII(CN)6]3- metalloligand is an attractive molecular building block for the construction of emissive molecule-based magnets realized by various bimetallic coordination topologies. Hexacyanidochromate(III) anion contributes significantly not only to the magnetic properties, offering the paramagnetic S = 3/2 ground state and six cyanide bridged mediating in the magnetic coupling, but also to the optical properties, as it can serve as an efficient sensitizer for the near-infrared luminescence of trivalent lanthanide ions. The presented material shows the coexistence of two different functionalities, which are magnetic ordering and luminescence. The expected interactions between these two properties could not be, however, observed due to low Curie temperature of 2.8 K. This can be overcome by the preparation of emissive [Cr(CN)6]-based magnets with the higher T C by the increase of coordination connectivity through cyanide bridges and the partial replacement of NdIII by GdIII revealing higher ground state spin of S = 7/2, or by the strongly anisotropic TbIII with the 7F6 ground multiplet. Alternatively, the Nd3+ admixtures can be implemented into three-dimensional Prussian Blue analogues frameworks based on 3d metal ions and [Cr(CN)6]3-, which are well-known for their high critical temperatures of magnetic ordering. Such implementation of strongly interacting near-infrared luminescent {NdIIICrIII} pairs into molecule-based magnets of high T C should result in the extraordinary magnetic control over the emission properties. This promising pathway is now intensively being investigated in our laboratories.

cln_elements.content:
All reagents, NdIIICl3·6H2O, K3[CrIII(CN)6], and pyrimidine N-oxide (pmmo, CAS: 17043-94-6) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification.

Synthesis of <bold>1</bold>

The 23.3 mg (0.065 mmol) portion of NdIIICl3·6H2O and the 12.5 mg (0.13 mmol) portion of pmmo were dissolved together in a minimal amount of water (0.3 mL) and heated to reach the boiling point. The resulting hot solution was quickly added to the freshly prepared solution of K3[CrIII(CN)6] (21.2 mg, 0.065 mmol), also dissolved in a small amount of water (0.3 mL). The mixture was stirred for several seconds, filtrated, and left in the dark for crystallization. The greenish platelet crystals of 1 started to appear after a few minutes. They were collected by the suction filtration, washed with water and ethanol, and dried in the air. The resulting monocrystalline material was stable during exposition on the air, and it was identified by the composition of {[NdIII(pmmo)2­(H2O)3]­[CrIII(CN)6]} (1) as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, and the CHN elemental analysis, supported by the thermogravimetric analysis (Figure S1). Yield: 13.0 mg, 33.4%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm–1). CN– stretching vibrations: 2156m, 2148m, 2136s, 2129m indicate that cyanides of [CrIII(CN)6]3– ions in 1 are both terminal and bridging. Others: 3590m, 3180s,br, O–H hydrogen bonding; 3110s, 3095s, stretching C–H; 1660m, δ­(H2O); 1595w, 1561m, 1556m, 1483m, 1475m, 1427vs, 1335w, 1253vs, 1230s, 1169w, 1124m, 1066w, 1059w, 1048w, 959vw, 929vw, 909vw, 860m, 853w, 831w, 819w, 688m, 680w, 652w, 588m, 576w, 519w, vibrational transitions of pmmo, including ν­(N–O) of 1253vs and various ν­(CC), ν­(CN), C–H and ring deformation. CHN elemental analysis. Anal. Calcd for Nd1Cr1C14H14N10O5 (1, M W = 598.56 g·mol–1): C, 28.1%; H, 2.4%; N, 23.4%. Found: C, 27.7%; H, 2.5%; N, 23.1%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All reagents, NdIIICl3⋅6H2O, K3[CrIII(CN)6], and pyrimidine N-oxide (pmmo, CAS: 17043-94-6) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification.

Synthesis of 1 

The 23.3 mg (0.065 mmol) portion of NdIIICl3⋅6H2O and the 12.5 mg (0.13 mmol) portion of pmmo were dissolved together in a minimal amount of water (0.3 mL) and heated to reach the boiling point. The resulting hot solution was quickly added to the freshly prepared solution of K3[CrIII(CN)6] (21.2 mg, 0.065 mmol), also dissolved in a small amount of water (0.3 mL). The mixture was stirred for several seconds, filtrated, and left in the dark for crystallization. The greenish platelet crystals of 1 started to appear after a few minutes. They were collected by the suction filtration, washed with water and ethanol, and dried in the air. The resulting monocrystalline material was stable during exposition on the air, and it was identified by the composition of {[NdIII(pmmo)2(H2O)3][CrIII(CN)6]} (1) as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, and the CHN elemental analysis, supported by the thermogravimetric analysis (Figure S1). Yield: 13.0 mg, 33.4%. IR spectrum (KBr, cm-1). CN- stretching vibrations: 2156m, 2148m, 2136s, 2129m indicate that cyanides of [CrIII(CN)6]3- ions in 1 are both terminal and bridging. Others: 3590m, 3180s,br, O-H hydrogen bonding; 3110s, 3095s, stretching C-H; 1660m, δ(H2O); 1595w, 1561m, 1556m, 1483m, 1475m, 1427vs, 1335w, 1253vs, 1230s, 1169w, 1124m, 1066w, 1059w, 1048w, 959vw, 929vw, 909vw, 860m, 853w, 831w, 819w, 688m, 680w, 652w, 588m, 576w, 519w, vibrational transitions of pmmo, including ν(N-O) of 1253vs and various ν(CC), ν(CN), C-H and ring deformation. CHN elemental analysis. Anal. Calcd for Nd1Cr1C14H14N10O5 (1, M W = 598.56 g⋅mol-1): C, 28.1%; H, 2.4%; N, 23.4%. Found: C, 27.7%; H, 2.5%; N, 23.1%.

cln_elements.content: The crystals of 1 reveal light greenish color which corresponds to the weak absorption in the visible region of 390–700 nm dominated by the broad component ranging from the UV part to around 450 nm, and relatively strong sharp band at 580 nm (). The solid state absorption spectrum of 1 was precisely investigated in the broad UV–vis-NIR range from 200 to 1000 nm. In contrast to the visible part of the spectrum, 1 exhibits very strong absorption of the UV light with the three maxima at 260, 290, and 380 nm. The broad and complex UV band with a significant visible tail to around 450 nm was deconvoluted into five components ascribed to the electronic transitions of [CrIII(CN)6]3–, and pmmo, as NdIII should reveal in this range rather sharp and much weaker f–f transitions. As presented in , four bands (1–4) are situated exclusively in the UV range below 350 K, and their maxima were found at 210, 234, 266, and 303 nm, respectively. Bands 1–3 are ascribed to the combined contributions from charge transfer transitions of [CrIII(CN)6]3– and singlet to singlet (π → π*) transitions of pmmo, as detected also in the precursors K3[Cr­(CN)6] and pure pmmo, and in the separately prepared reference sample of the lanthanum-containing analogue with the formula of {[LaIII(pmmo)2­(H2O)3]­[CrIII(CN)6]} (1 La ) (Figures S6–S7, Table S3, and details of the reference samples in Supporting Information). Bands 4 and 5 represent also both the hexacyanidometallate complex and pmmo, as the related transitions of CrIII (4A2g → 4T1g, band 4; 4A2g → 4T2g, band 5) and pmmo (n → π*) can be detected in this range. In addition, one more broad and weak component ranging from the UV to the visible range, and centered at 483 nm, was also found, and it can be assigned mainly to the spin-forbidden transitions of pmmo (triplet → singlet: n → π*), while the additional contribution from the 4A2g → 2T2g transition of CrIII, positioned in this range, should much smaller. The Vis-NIR part of the spectrum between 465 and 870 nm is dominated by a series of sharp bands ascribed to the f–f electronic transitions of NdIII (bands 7–14) as those bands are not observed in the lanthanum-containing 1 La reference (Figure S7). The respective maxima are situated at 465, 516, 579, 626, 681, 744, 798, and 870 nm, respectively, and they can be interpreted in terms of the transitions from 4I9/2 ground multiplet to the 2G9/2, 4G11/2, 2K15/2 (band 7), 4G7/2, 4G9/2, 2K13/2 (band 8), 2G7/2, 4G5/2 (band 9), 2H11/2 (band 10), 4F9/2 (band 11), 4S3/2, 4F7/2 (band 12), 2H9/2, 4F5/2 (band 13), and 4F3/2 (band 14) excited states of NdIII.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties

The crystals of 1 reveal light greenish color which corresponds to the weak absorption in the visible region of 390-700 nm dominated by the broad component ranging from the UV part to around 450 nm, and relatively strong sharp band at 580 nm (). The solid state absorption spectrum of 1 was precisely investigated in the broad UV-vis-NIR range from 200 to 1000 nm. In contrast to the visible part of the spectrum, 1 exhibits very strong absorption of the UV light with the three maxima at 260, 290, and 380 nm. The broad and complex UV band with a significant visible tail to around 450 nm was deconvoluted into five components ascribed to the electronic transitions of [CrIII(CN)6]3-, and pmmo, as NdIII should reveal in this range rather sharp and much weaker f-f transitions. As presented in , four bands (1-4) are situated exclusively in the UV range below 350 K, and their maxima were found at 210, 234, 266, and 303 nm, respectively. Bands 1-3 are ascribed to the combined contributions from charge transfer transitions of [CrIII(CN)6]3- and singlet to singlet (π → π*) transitions of pmmo, as detected also in the precursors K3[Cr(CN)6] and pure pmmo, and in the separately prepared reference sample of the lanthanum-containing analogue with the formula of {[LaIII(pmmo)2(H2O)3][CrIII(CN)6]} (1  La ) (Figures S6-S7, Table S3, and details of the reference samples in Supporting Information). Bands 4 and 5 represent also both the hexacyanidometallate complex and pmmo, as the related transitions of CrIII (4A2g → 4T1g, band 4; 4A2g → 4T2g, band 5) and pmmo (n → π*) can be detected in this range. In addition, one more broad and weak component ranging from the UV to the visible range, and centered at 483 nm, was also found, and it can be assigned mainly to the spin-forbidden transitions of pmmo (triplet → singlet: n → π*), while the additional contribution from the 4A2g → 2T2g transition of CrIII, positioned in this range, should much smaller. The Vis-NIR part of the spectrum between 465 and 870 nm is dominated by a series of sharp bands ascribed to the f-f electronic transitions of NdIII (bands 7-14) as those bands are not observed in the lanthanum-containing 1  La  reference (Figure S7). The respective maxima are situated at 465, 516, 579, 626, 681, 744, 798, and 870 nm, respectively, and they can be interpreted in terms of the transitions from 4I9/2 ground multiplet to the 2G9/2, 4G11/2, 2K15/2 (band 7), 4G7/2, 4G9/2, 2K13/2 (band 8), 2G7/2, 4G5/2 (band 9), 2H11/2 (band 10), 4F9/2 (band 11), 4S3/2, 4F7/2 (band 12), 2H9/2, 4F5/2 (band 13), and 4F3/2 (band 14) excited states of NdIII.
